A woman who has refused to leave a Los Angeles-area Airbnb is now demanding to be paid $100,000 to get out, according to a settlement offer reviewed by the Los Angeles Times.

The host, Sascha Jovanovic, said the woman’s stay was scheduled to end in April 2022, but she then refused to move out. Elizabeth Hirschhorn, dubbed as the “tenant from hell”, has been living rent-free ever since.

Mr Jovanovic, who owns the estate where the homestay is located in the hills of Brentwood, told the Times he cannot go into his home and “know that I’m safe when a potentially hostile person is living there.

“I’m thinking about it at all times,” he added.

Hirschhorn declined to speak to the outlet to share her side of the story; however, her attorney, Colin Walshok, argued that she was not required to pay rent.

“The landlord broke the law and tried to make money by renting out an illegal bootleg unit,” he told the Times. “After he was caught, instead of doing the right thing, he has resorted to bullying, harassment and the filing of frivolous lawsuits containing elaborate false stories, all in attempt to cover his tracks.”

After deciding to put out his small guesthouse for rent, Mr Jovanovic approved a long-term stay for Ms Hirschhorn in September of 2021.

The space was rented for six months at a rate of $105 per night, which with fees brought the total to $20,793 for 187 nights.

The pair got on well in the beginning, sharing tea and small talk, but there were some warning signs that Mr Jovanovic said he should have listened to.

Another Airbnb host had put out a review on Ms Hirschhorn’s profile that said “she had a lot of particular needs that I eventually could not accommodate.”

And then, Mr Jovanovic claims, he went into the guesthouse to check on electric blinds that had stopped working and noticed there was water damage and signs of mould around the sink, problems he says were not there before Hirschhorn arrived.

Wanting to repair the sink and stop the spread of mould, the landlord said he offered to pay his guest to stay at a hotel for a few days and also offered $1,000 toward a hotel of her choice, according to Airbnb messages and emails exchanged between the two.

However, Ms Hirschhorn declined, saying: “I don’t feel safe being forced to vacate with a housing disability and the high risks of Covid-19 complications.” She then quoted L.A. County’s Covid-19 Tenant Protections Resolution and showed a 2011 doctor’s note pointing out chemical sensitivities.

In addition, the emails showed he had also offered her to stay in his home, which she declined.

Ms Hirschhorn is now counter-suing Mr Jovanovic and claims that he “inappropriately invited” her to move into his house with him.

Ms Hirschhorn’s Airbnb stay was scheduled to end on 19 March; however, Mr Jovanovic offered her a month’s extension in order to find somewhere else to live, something that backfired on him because Airbnb was then free from getting involved in the dispute.

“Once everything went to hell, Airbnb was out,” said Sebastian Rucci, an attorney representing Mr Jovanovic, according to the Times.

Then came the new deadline and Ms Hirschhorn stayed put. In an email, she said: “I can’t leave on Apr. 12 as relocation and funding plan is not in place, it would be unsafe. If you want to work something out I am willing to do that.”

Since then, she has not paid any rent and she still remains — over 540 days later — having claimed in a May 2022 email that “Your actions and alleged repairs are made knowing that of my disability requiring accommodation, I believe it was made to harass and scare me.”

Mr Jovanovic tried serving multiple eviction notices, but a housing department investigator, Pedro Gonzalez, said Mr Jovanovic had to withdraw his eviction notices as the building did not comply with the city’s building-safety rules.

But Ms Hirschhorn refused to let the host inside the property so it could be updated to comply with the city’s building codes.

Mr Jovanovic is incredulous, telling the Times: “How can you stay in someone’s home for a year and a half and not have any feeling of embarrassment or responsibility?”

The Independent has contacted Airbnb for a comment.

The Accelerator Neutrino Neutron Interaction Experiment (ANNIE) is a 26-ton water-based neutrino detector at Fermilab on the Booster Neutrino Beam (BNB), small by particle physics standards but with big ambitions. The goal of the effort is to develop a next-generation neutrino detector using advanced photosensors and new experimental techniques, all while making important progress in understanding how neutrinos interact with matter. Measurements of final-state neutron multiplicity from neutrino-nucleus interactions will improve our understanding of the complex, many-body dynamics of neutrino-nucleus interactions and thus help to reduce dominant systematics on future long-baseline neutrino oscillation measurements.

Identifying and counting final state neutrons also provides a useful experimental handle for signal-background separation in future neutrino experiments. Two enabling technologies make this measurement possible: (1) the first application of Large Area Picosecond Photodetectors (LAPPDs), which will allow detailed timing-based reconstruction of the primary neutrino interaction, and (2) the first use of gadolinium-enhanced water on a high energy neutrino beam to efficiently count final-state neutrons. Phase I of ANNIE, designed to provide a measurement of critical neutron backgrounds, was successfully completed in 2017. Phase II detector for the full physics program of the experiment was installed in July 2019 and currently, it is under commissioning. The collaboration plans to start taking neutrino beam data in December 2019.

title: BNB Chain Experiences Significant DeFi Exodus: Nearly $2 Billion Leaves in 2023 - The Currency Analytics
content:
In a dramatic and unexpected turn of events, BNB Chain, formerly known as Binance Smart Chain, has witnessed a staggering departure of funds from its decentralized finance (DeFi) ecosystem. As the crypto world grapples with mounting global regulatory scrutiny aimed at centralized crypto finance (CeFi) service providers, close to $2 billion worth of cryptocurrencies have flowed out of the platform this year alone. This significant shift has left industry observers pondering the implications for BNB Chain’s sustainability and the broader crypto industry.

The Rise and Fall of DeFi on BNB Chain

Decentralized finance, or DeFi, has been hailed as a revolutionary movement within the world of cryptocurrencies. Its primary goal is to create a more inclusive and open financial system by eliminating intermediaries and facilitating peer-to-peer transactions. BNB Chain, an offshoot of the renowned cryptocurrency exchange Binance, was once a thriving epicenter for DeFi projects. However, recent developments have cast a shadow over its prospects.

For those unfamiliar with DeFi, it represents a paradigm shift in the financial sector, where traditional financial intermediaries are replaced by smart contracts and blockchain technology. Users can access a wide array of financial services, such as lending, borrowing, and trading, without relying on banks or other traditional financial institutions. This disruptive innovation has garnered immense attention and investment within the crypto space.

BNB Chain’s DeFi ecosystem was a shining example of this disruptive force. It attracted a plethora of projects, users, and developers who sought to harness the power of blockchain to create a decentralized financial infrastructure. Binance, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, had thrown its considerable weight behind the BNB Chain, which further bolstered its appeal.

Regulatory Storm Clouds Gather

However, the crypto landscape has not been without its challenges. In recent times, the industry has faced increasing scrutiny from regulators worldwide. Concerns over money laundering, fraud, and investor protection have led governments and financial watchdogs to take a closer look at cryptocurrencies and their associated services.

BNB Chain’s woes are intrinsically tied to this global regulatory crackdown. As governments seek to impose stricter rules on cryptocurrency exchanges and platforms, many investors and projects have grown wary. The recent outflow of funds from BNB Chain can be seen as a response to these concerns.

It’s important to note that Binance, the parent company of BNB Chain, has faced regulatory heat in various jurisdictions. Authorities in several countries, including the United States, have raised questions about Binance’s compliance with local laws. This has created uncertainty among BNB Chain users, prompting some to reconsider their involvement in the ecosystem.

The $2 Billion Exodus

The exodus of funds from BNB Chain has raised eyebrows across the crypto industry. In the span of just one year, nearly $2 billion worth of cryptocurrencies have left the platform. This sizable shift in assets is not only a blow to BNB Chain but also a stark reminder of the volatility and unpredictability of the crypto market.

The reasons behind this mass departure are multifaceted. First and foremost, the regulatory environment has become increasingly unpredictable, leading many participants to seek safer havens for their crypto assets. Additionally, concerns about the sustainability and security of DeFi projects on BNB Chain have played a role. Smart contract vulnerabilities, hacks, and rug pulls have plagued the ecosystem, eroding confidence in its long-term viability.

Furthermore, the very essence of DeFi’s ethos—a trustless and decentralized financial system—has been called into question as centralized exchanges like Binance continue to exert influence and control over their affiliated chains. Some argue that this defeats the purpose of DeFi and undermines its core principles.

Implications for the Crypto Industry

The departure of funds from BNB Chain carries significant implications for the broader crypto industry. It underscores the delicate balance that DeFi projects must strike between decentralization and regulatory compliance. While DeFi aims to empower users and create a more equitable financial system, it cannot operate in a vacuum, immune to the laws and regulations that govern traditional finance.

Moreover, the BNB Chain case highlights the importance of security and transparency within the DeFi space. Investors and users are becoming increasingly discerning, demanding greater scrutiny of smart contracts, project audits, and transparent governance mechanisms. To thrive in this evolving landscape, DeFi platforms must prioritize these aspects to regain trust and confidence.

In Conclusion

The substantial outflow of funds from BNB Chain serves as a cautionary tale for the crypto industry. It demonstrates the vulnerability of even well-established DeFi ecosystems in the face of regulatory pressures and security concerns. As the crypto world grapples with evolving challenges, it is crucial for participants to adapt, innovate, and find sustainable solutions that can navigate the complex regulatory landscape while staying true to the principles of decentralization.

BNB Chain’s future remains uncertain, and its fate will be closely watched by industry insiders and enthusiasts alike. Regardless of the outcome, the lessons learned from this episode will undoubtedly shape the trajectory of DeFi and the broader cryptocurrency industry for years to come.
